text: Marie-Aimée Roger-Miclos, from a 1903 publication. Marie-Aimée Roger-Miclos (May 1, 1860 — May 19, 1951Acte de décès n° 1037 (vue 15/31). Archives en ligne de la Ville de Paris, état-civil du 16ème arrondissement, registre des décès de 1951.) was a French pianist. ==Early life== Marie-Aimée Miclos was born in Toulouse.Marie Roger-Miclos, Sophie Drinker Institut.Hugues Imbert, "Mme. Roger-Miclos" Guide musical (February 25, 1894): 196-198. She studied at the Conservatoire de Toulouse and the Conservatoire de Paris, with and with Henri Herz.David Dubal, The Art of the Piano: Its Performers, Literature, and Recordings (Hal Leonard Corporation 2004): 294-295. ==Career== Several composers dedicated compositions to Roger-Miclos."Category:Roger-Miclos, Marie" IMSLP Petrucci Music Library. Joseph O'Kelly dedicated a piano work to Roger-Miclos in 1884.Axel Klein, O'Kelly: An Irish Musical Family in Nineteenth-Century France (Axel Klein 2014): 59, 420. Camille Saint-Saëns dedicated a piano piece to Roger-Miclos, which she premiered in 1891.Sabina Teller Ratner, Camille Saint-Saëns, 1835-1921: A Thematic Catalogue of His Complete Works (Oxford University Press 2002): 393-394. Roger-Miclos played in London in 1890"Recent Concerts" The Saturday Review of Politics, Literature, Science, and Art (June 14, 1890): 738. and 1894."Pianoforte Recitals" The Musical Times (June 1, 1894): 391-392. She toured German- speaking cities in 1893, 1894, and 1897. She toured in the United States and Canada in the 1902–1903 season."Music and Musicians" The Theatre (March 1903): 77-78.David Converse, "The World of To-Day" Boston Home Journal (January 3, 1902): 6. "She comes from Southern France, the land of fire and passion, and is an artist of interesting and unconventional qualities, possessing a strongly marked sense of rhythm, brilliant and incisive touch, and her playing is marked with certainty, that adds tonal charm to brilliancy," observed one reviewer, adding "As a pianiste she is an artistic diplomat.""Chicago Grand Opera Season" The Muse (April 1903): 209. In 1905, she made recordings of Mendelssohn and Chopin works.Charles Timbrell, French Pianism: A Historical Perspective (Hal Leonard Corporation 1999): 60-61. Frank Hoffmann, ed., Encyclopedia of Recorded Sound (Routledge 2004): 1638. She also taught piano, at the Paris Conservatoire."The Most Difficult Piano Piece" Current Literature (September 1895): 226. American painter George Da Maduro Peixotto made a portrait of her in 1893. She was also the subject of a medal made by French artist , exhibited in 1909.Leonard Forrer, ed., Biographical dictionary of medallists (Baldwin 1923): 391. ==Personal life== Marie-Aimée Roger-Miclos married twice. Her first husband, Roger, was a railroad inspector; they married in 1881, and he died in 1887. Her second husband was fellow musician Louis-Charles Battaille, the son of Charles-Amable Battaille; they married in 1905, and he died in 1937. She died in Paris in 1951, aged 91 years.Charles Battaille, Artlyriquefr. ==References== ==External links== * Category:1860 births Category:1951 deaths Category:French women classical pianists Category:19th-century women musicians Category:20th-century French women musicians Category:People from Toulouse Category:19th-century classical pianists Category:20th-century classical pianists Category:Conservatoire de Paris alumni Category:Academics of the Conservatoire de Paris
